tossups.question: A twenty-first-century response to this play by Darren Canady is about a transgender woman named Veronica and is entitled TRANSit. A character in this play explains “I lie a lot. It helps me control the world” after observing that a man looks like he’s been “reading Chinese poetry” and “drinking lukewarm sugarless tea.” A woman tells its protagonist to pretend “that you are free of your own history. And I am free of my history” before ending its first scene by shouting “GROOVE!” In its final scene, a long description of an invitation to a (*) tenement apartment transitions to a belittling request to “rub bellies” and “do the nasty.” At its climax, a man in a suit angrily tells a seductive 30-year-old redhead that murdering white people would “make us all sane” after she goads him by calling him an Uncle Tom. Set in a New York City subway car, this is—for 10 points—what 1964 play in which Lula teases Clay before stabbing him, written by Amiri Baraka?
tossups.answer: Dutchman <Literature - American>

tossups.question: An author with this surname attacked Robert Dahl’s polyarchy thesis in a 1969 book arguing that the power exerted by business is the dominant influence on the state, not merely one of a plurality of competing groups. That author with this surname wrote The State in Capitalist Society, and was attacked in a 2013 Daily Mail article as “the man who hated Britain.” Another man with this surname resigned from Parliament to run the International Rescue Committee. A politician with this surname was criticized for campaigning in front of a large (*) stone tablet engraved with six pledges, including “controls on immigration.” That politician was roundly mocked over a photograph of him awkwardly eating a bacon sandwich. For 10 points, identify this last name shared by the Marxist sociologist Ralph and his sons David and Ed, who competed against one another in 2010 for leadership of the Labour Party.
tossups.answer: Miliband [accept Ralph Miliband, David Miliband, or Ed Miliband] <Mythology and Other>

tossups.question: A gene that encodes for this process names a family of transcription factors binding to the minor groove in DNA, a subset of the high mobility group known as SOX genes. This process results in the formation of a namesake nucleus of the medial preoptic area of the hypothalamus. Mutations in the Desert hedgehog homolog gene may cause failure of this process in Swyer’s snydrome. DMRT-1, a gene most associated with this process, is related to the Drosophila “double” gene. A mutation in mineralo·corticoid synthesis causes a condition in which this process occurs atypically, (*) congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Granulosa cells of a namesake set of “cords” stimulate this non-folliculogenesis process by producing anti-Mullerian hormone. This process occurs atypically in mutations that affect the androgen receptor. For 10 points, name this process that begins when a fetus is about seven weeks old and sees the formation of either testes or ovaries.
tossups.answer: sexual differentiation [or sexual dimorphism; accept equivalent answers like determining sex; accept specific examples like differentiating into a woman (man); accept development of sex organs, development of gonads, or gonadogenesis] <Science - Biology>

tossups.question: A cartoon in support of this policy shows an enormous floating head labeled a “pest” with several women holding an object labeled “federation” in opposition. Advocates of this policy claimed it would end widespread gambling on Pakapoo, and it became more popular after the spread of “Kanaka” forced labor. The slogan “populate or perish” was used in a successful campaign to end this policy, which was weakened by the arrival of the so-called “Beautiful Balts.” Postwar attempts to increase the labor pool while maintaining this policy included the Big Brother Movement and the influx of the Ten Pound Poms. The law enforcing this policy led to the demand that (*) Egon Kisch recite the Lord’s Prayer in Scottish Gaelic. It began with a bill written by Alfred Deakin in 1901 and was not dismantled until the Migration Act of 1966. For 10 points, identify this longtime policy against Eastern European and Asian immigrants to a country with capital Canberra.
tossups.answer: White Australia policy [accept equivalent answers like non-white immigration restriction in Australia; prompt on immigration restriction; prompt on immigration restriction in Australia with “who was being restricted?”] <History - Other/World>

tossups.question: A painting by this artist uses a partially-hidden top hat on the right-hand side to stand in for a letter in the word “Hat,” while the word for “thread” is superimposed on the title figure. This artist depicted the title figures holding long, blank, white scrolls in the controversial painting The Evangelists. This artist painted the five-panel polyptych Spanish Women while on tour with Diaghilev, and this artist created the costumes for the 1926 Ballet Russes revival of The Firebird. This artist organized the exhibitions Target and (*) Donkey’s Tail after displaying several primitivist paintings with Jack of Diamonds. This artist’s Futurist phase included The Cyclist and culminated in the invention of Rayonism alongside longtime collaborator Mikhail Larionov. For 10 points, name this most prominent woman among the Russian modernist painters.
tossups.answer: Natalia (Sergeevna) Goncharova <Arts - Visual>

tossups.question: The measured Drell–Yan cross section in proton-antiproton collisions at the Tevatron has a strong enhancement explained by the presence of this particle. The cancellation of two one-loop “box diagrams” explain why decays involving this particle that are allowed by conservation laws but have a “delta-S” of 1 are suppressed; that mechanism is named for Glashow, Iliopoulos, and Maiani. This particle couples to both left- and right-handed states, and the strength of coupling to it is equal to the fundamental charge over the quantity (*) “sine theta times cosine theta,” where theta is an angle whose sine-squared is about 0.23. The decay of the standard model Higgs boson into two of these particles has a branching ratio of 2.64%. The consequences of this particle were first detected in the Gargamelle bubble chamber at CERN, and it was later directly detected in the UA1 and UA2 experiments in 1983. The interaction between neutrinos and electrons is mediated by this particle, which has a mass of 90 GeV. For 10 points, name this electrically-neutral mediator of the weak force.
tossups.answer: Z0 boson <Science - Physics>

tossups.question: During an event in this city, efforts to care for hungry children were thwarted by rumors that the so-called “Kiddies Scheme” was a secret conspiracy to convert its youth. That event in this city began when a tramway company demanded its workers forswear membership in the ITGWU, leading to a series of “sympathetic strikes.” James Larkin’s speech from the balcony of this city’s Imperial Hotel triggered a baton charge by police during an extended strike opposed by William “Murder” Murphy. This city’s 6-month (*) “lockout” in 1913 presaged a later event that saw the execution of two journalists outside the Portobello barracks. That event in this city led the author of the Black Diaries to be “hanged on a comma” after a scheme to ship German guns in support of that event failed. This city’s post office was used as a headquarters during an uprising led by James Connolly and Patrick Pearse. For 10 points, name this city that saw the failed 1916 Easter Rising, the capital of Ireland.
tossups.answer: Dublin <History - European>

tossups.question: After visiting this country, Sergei Esenin published his impressions of it in the essay “Iron Mirgorod.” A book named for this country fictionalizes the engineer Solomon Trone and his wife Florence as Mr. and Mrs. Adams, and includes photographs published separately by the journal Ogonek. Maxim Gorky wrote an essay calling one of this country’s cities the “City of the Yellow Devil” because of his disastrous 1906 visit here, during which he was scandalously evicted from three separate hotels. As special (*) correspondents for Pravda, two authors observed this country’s customs on a ten-week road trip across it in 1935. Vladimir Mayakovsky wrote a book about his “discovery” of this country, which is described as “single-story” in the title of a travelogue by Ilf and Petrov. After his exile, Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn spent over twenty years living in—for 10 points—what country that fascinated many Soviet authors because of its adherence to capitalism?
tossups.answer: United States of America [or U.S.A.; or “One-Story America” or “Single-Story America” or “Odnoetazhnaya Amerika” or “My Discovery of America”] <Literature - European>

tossups.question: The colophon of a text in this language claims that the number of colors of the horses and magic stones described in it makes it impossible to recite from memory. In the fourteenth through seventeenth centuries, the major form of poetry in this language consisted of seven-syllable couplets that rhyme stressed and unstressed syllables. Medieval praise poems in this language were written by the “Poets of the Nobility,” who succeeded the twelfth- and thirteenth-century “Poets of the Princes.” In a text in this language, a king and one of his warriors are so intent on playing games of (*) chess that they ignore reports of ravens ferociously fighting squires. Texts in this language like “The Dream of Rhonabwy” are included in the Red Book of Hergest. The “four branches” of stories in this language were translated into English by Lady Charlotte Guest. For 10 points, name this language of the Book of Taliesin and the Mabinogion.
tossups.answer: Middle Welsh [or Cymraeg; don’t accept “Old Welsh”] <Literature - Other/World>

tossups.question: A limestone jubilee shrine built in this city is often nicknamed for its white color. A building in this city was the first to be built from standardized blocks called talatat. A building near this city has three terraced colonnades that are connected by long double ramps. A model boat probably once floated in a basin at the center of a red quartzite building in this city dubbed the “Red Chapel” or “Chapelle Rouge.” The Romans called a site near this city the (*) “Mem·nonium” after a pair of statues located in it. A complex in this city includes ten huge pylons, and houses 134 enormous, relief-decorated columns in its Great Hypostyle Hall. The largest surviving ancient obelisk was erected at this site by Hat·shep·sut. The Valley of the Kings was located across from—for 10 points—what Egyptian city home to the temple complexes at Luxor and Karnak?
tossups.answer: Thebes [or Waset; accept Luxor or Karnak until they’re mentioned] <Mythology and Other>

tossups.question: A “moral minimalism” defined by limited confrontation in one of these places called “Hampton” was described in a book by M.P. Baumgartner. Myron Orfield developed a system for classifying these places that describes three types of them as “at-risk.” According to a book by Eric Oliver titled for “Democracy” in them, these places are characterized by restricted opportunities for civic participation. Kenneth Jackson described the spread of these places in the book (*) Crabgrass Frontier. They aren’t ethnic enclaves, but Herbert Gans wrote about one of these places called Willingboro, rejecting the negative cultural image of them promoted by songs such as Malvina Reynolds’ “Little Boxes.” For 10 points, name these places whose residents often commute into nearby large cities.
tossups.answer: suburbs [or suburbia] <Social Science>

tossups.question: In 2018, declassified documents from this country’s security service revealed “Operation Cross,” a nearly-launched plan to set fire to a church in one neighboring country and blame it on another. A Prime Minister from this country was brutally murdered by members of the IMRO, who cut off the hand he used to sign the Treaty of Niš. The daughter of one of this country’s leaders established a “Roerich Year” after meeting the son of Nicholas Roerich in India. This country used the (*) Belene labor camp during a forced assimilation campaign called the “Revival Process” that was aimed at its Muslim minority. The Treaty of Neuilly-sur-Seine [noy-EE sewr ssehn] forced this country to give up many of its territories after World War I. The April Conspiracy targeted a longtime leader of this country, who was known as “Uncle Toshi” and became the longest-serving leader in the Eastern Bloc. Todor Zhivkov led—for 10 points—what Eastern European country whose capital is Sofia?
tossups.answer: Bulgaria <History - Mediterranean+>

tossups.question: A 2002 paper by Courtois and Pieprzyk studies this algorithm as a system of quadratic equations that in turn leads to an “eXtended Sparse Linearization,” or XSL. In 2011, Bogdanov et al. examined the use of bicliques as the first effective “key recovery” approach toward this algorithm. The Galois field of order 2 is used to perform an “S-box” transformation during the SubBytes step of this algorithm. A “schedule” in this algorithm produces the numerous keys added at the end of each of its rounds, which is recommended as numbering (*) 14 for its most stringent form. This algorithm is a specific variant of the block cipher Rijndael [“Rhine”-dahl] that two Belgian researchers submitted to an open contest by NIST to replace a notably brute force vulnerable protocol. This protocol supports keys with a maximum of 256 bits, and it officially succeeded DES in 2002. For 10 points, name this encryption “standard” officially adopted by the U.S. federal government.
tossups.answer: AES [or Advanced Encryption Standard; accept specific key length variants like AES-256; prompt on Rijndael or block cipher] <Science - Other>

tossups.question: A dirge commonly attributed to this woman begins “O Death, Rock me asleep.” The words “circa Regna tonat” end each stanza of a poem written in response to this woman’s death, which includes the line “These bloody days have broken my heart.” Shortly before dying, she inscribed the phrase “Remember me when you do pray / that hope doth lead from day to day” in a Book of Hours she gave to her friend (*) Margaret Lee. Most critics believe that this is the woman whose “fair neck” is “graven with diamonds” that spell “Noli me tangere” in a sonnet comparing her to a fleeing deer. That sonnet was written by an author imprisoned in the Tower of London under suspicion of committing adultery with her. “Whoso List to Hunt” was written by a poet infatuated with this woman: Thomas Wyatt. For 10 points, name this second wife of Henry VIII who died by being beheaded.
tossups.answer: Anne Boleyn <Literature - British>

tossups.question: A variant of this system used in one city has increased the rates of leash usage to 80% as part of the “Civilized Dog-Raising” program. This system emerged in part from a similar program developed by Ant Financial under the name “Sesame.” Existing infrastructure, such as a project translated as “Sharp Eyes” and the Skynet network are expected to help in implementing this system, which will make its country the largest (*) video camera market in the world. This system, which builds on the “smile to pay” facial recognition installed in many of its country’s KFCs, is lagging far behind its intended 2020 rollout. One incarnation of this system relies on information collected by Tencent from QQ chats and data collected by AliPay. So far, this system primarily restricts hotel and flight bookings in areas under pilot programs. The “Nosedive” episode of Black Mirror is uncomfortably reminiscent of—for 10 points—what still-nascent Chinese system that tracks citizens and assigns a score based on their behavior?
tossups.answer: Chinese Social Credit system [or SCS; or shèhuì xìnyòng tǐxì] <Modern World>

tossups.question: In a variant of the Ritter reaction, these compounds react with nitriles to generate oxazoline heterocycles. In the Eschenmoser fragmentation, ketones with this extra functionalization are treated with tosyl·hydrazine, decomposing into alkynes. Treating an electrophilic ketone like benzil with an unstabilized sulfonium ylide will yield a compound with this functional group. Hepatic cytochrome P450 enzymes act on benzene to make a carcinogenic compound with this functional group. They can be asymmetrically synthesized by using a chiral (*) di·ethyl tartrate ligand conjugated to a titanium center as a catalyst. A fructose-derived catalyst is used in a synthesis of these compounds named for Shi; that reaction is asymmetric just like the Sharpless reaction to form these compounds. Reacting alkenes with a peroxy acid, like mCPBA, makes—for 10 points—what organic functional group characterized by a three-membered ring containing oxygen?
tossups.answer: epoxides [or oxiranes; accept epoxidations] <Science - Chemistry>

tossups.question: Elliott Carter unusually used this title for the first movement of his symphony “sum fluxae pretium spei.” A 1932 piece with this title ends with the lullaby “Naenia B.M.V.” and was the first major success for Luigi Dallapiccola. A piece with this title includes the repeated declaration “the detail of the pattern is movement,” and intersperses descriptions of geometric constructions with sections in Sacred Harp style. That 2013 piece with this title begins with the repeated statement “To the side.” This term is used for J. S. Bach’s only work for solo (*) flute. A B-minor Bach piece in this genre includes a “Double” after each movement. Caroline Shaw wrote a piece with this title “for 8 Voices.” Bach arranged the “Preludio” from an E-major piece in this genre as the “Sinfonia” for Cantata 29. This term was often used to mean “suite,” and a D-minor Bach suite with this title ends with a massive Chaconne. For 10 points, give this title of three violin solos that Bach paired with three Sonatas.
tossups.answer: partitas [accept chorale partitas; accept Sonatas and Partitas; accept Partita for 8 Voices; prompt on suite by asking “What’s the specific title?”; anti-prompt on allemande by asking “What’s the title of the whole piece?”] <Arts - Auditory>

tossups.question: A philosopher with this surname accused opponents of a sexist “conflation of responsible work with market wage-earning” which thus becomes a “perfect reproduction of Poor Law thinking.” The most famous paper by that philosopher with this surname attacks thinkers who hold that the answer to the title question is “to compensate people for having bad luck”; that paper’s answer to its title question is to ensure that people stand in relations of (*) equality to each other. A philosopher with this surname opposed “luck egalitarianism” with her theory of “democratic equality.” Private Government and “What Is the Point of Equality?” are by a feminist philosopher with this surrname who now chairs the philosophy department at the University of Michigan. A thinker with this last name edited the New Left Review in the 1960s and ‘70s and wrote Considerations on Western Marxism. For 10 points, give this surname of the man who analyzed the role of “print capitalism” in nationalism in the book Imagined Communities.
tossups.answer: Anderson [accept Elizabeth S(ecor) Anderson or Perry Anderson or Benedict Anderson] <Philosophy>

tossups.question: In a paper about these people, Kelly Lytle Hernandez details how local officials created a “little barbershop for chronic offenders,” which forcibly shaved the heads of these individuals to aid in future identification. Places like Elysian Park were converted into concentration camps for these people. The man who turned the NRA into an extremist political organization, Harlon Carter, pushed for federal action against these people, which resulted in a plan devised by Joseph Swing. These people were doused with DDT during a period in which they took advantage of (*) Public Law 45. The deadliest traffic accident in U.S. history saw 32 of these people killed when a bus carrying them was hit by a train outside Chualar. A labor shortage during World War II led to a program for a small number of these people to enter legally, but fell far short of meeting demand, which led the Eisenhower administration to launch Operation Wetback. For 10 points, identify these individuals who sought temporary work by crossing the southern U.S. border.
tossups.answer: braceros [or migrant workers from Mexico; prompt on partial answer; prompt on wetbacks before mentioned, but as that’s a racial slur be sure to side-eye whoever says that pretty sharply] <History - American>

tossups.question: A scholar of this language was accused of having a “child syndrome” by a businessman who ghostwrote much of the book Invading the Sacred, an incident discussed in Martha Nussbaum’s The Clash Within. This language’s “hegemonic” force has been critiqued by Sheldon Pollock, who has been accused of “secularizing” this language. An analysis of writings on “sexual fluids” in this language begins the book Women, Androgynes, and Other Mythical Beasts. NYU Press published a Loeb-like “Library” in this language sponsored by the (*) Clay family. Five texts from this language were translated by Max Müller as the first volume of his series of Sacred Books. In 2009, a hugely controversial history “alternative history” was published by Wendy Doniger, a scholar of this language. A “forest” or “wilderness” names the tenth of a set of 108 sacred texts in—for 10 points—what language of the Upanishads?
tossups.answer: Sanskrit [or samskritam] <Religion>  Chicago Open 2019: What If We Kissed 😳 in the Non-Western Art Distribution 😳  Edited by Chris Ray, Jacob Reed, Alston Boyd, Will Holub-Moorman, Jonathan Magin, and Sriram Pendyala, with contributions by Wonyoung Jang and Michael Kearney.  Packet by Steampunk Zoo Sci-Fi Fusion Wedding with Beatles (Halle Friedman, Emmett Laurie, Matt Mitchell, Vishwa Shanmugam) and Groupon Ya Grinch (Boyang Jiao, Sean Smiley, Jerry Vinokurov, Matt Weiner)  Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: This man called upon all “Asiatic” peoples to unite, and claimed to have been recognized as divine by an Egyptian priest. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man who founded the Canaanite Temple in Newark, New Jersey. After moving to Chicago, he founded another institution preaching to the descendents of the Moabites.

Noble Drew founded this religious institution, considered by some to be the first Islamic organization in America. Its name derives in part from its belief that all black people in America were of Moroccan descent.
The mysterious Wallace Fard Muhammad eventually left Moorish Science to found this religious movement, which was later led by Elijah Muhammad.

bonuses.leadin: The pioneering mixed-race teacher Mary S. Peake provided her services to a group of people who were given this status. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this legal designation given to slaves by Union forces to prevent them from being returned to their Confederate owners. A “Grand Camp” named for this status was established near the future site of Hampton University after thousands flocked to Fort Monroe, Virginia in hopes of emancipation.

While serving at Fort Monroe, this Union general was the first to classify slaves as contraband. This general was relieved of command after refusing to assault Fort Fisher after earlier being turned back in the Bermuda Hundred campaign, but is better known for a non-combat role.

Later in the Civil War, a “Freedmen’s Colony” consisting of contraband slaves was established on this island in North Carolina, which was once the site of a disastrous “lost colony” led by Walter Raleigh.

bonuses.leadin: This author likes to weave narratives by overlapping voices across time periods in novels like An Explanation of the Birds. For 10 points each:
answers: António Lobo Antunes (The dictatorship is Portugal’s Estado Novo.)
parts: Name this doctor-turned-author, who used that “polyphonic” technique in novels depicting life under his country’s dictatorship, Act of the Damned and The Inquisitor’s Manual.
Antunes’s polyphonic narratives were largely inspired by this author, who created characters like the Snopes family in his novels set in Yoknapatawpha County.

In an essay on the metaphysics of time in The Sound and the Fury, this critic accused Faulker of “abolishing the future,” comparing his characters to people facing backwards in a moving car. His introduction to Nathalie Saurrate’s Portrait of a Man Unknown coined the term “anti-novel.”

bonuses.leadin: A theatre company tries to tour with the play Golfo the Shepherdess in this man’s film The Travelling Players, which uses just eighty shots for its 4-hour runtime. For 10 points each:
answers: Hungary [or Magyarország] (The directors are Miklós Jancsó and Béla Tarr.) <Arts - Audiovisual, Other>
parts: Name this director who grouped his films into trilogies of History, Silence, and Borders. He’s best-known for 1998’s Eternity and a Day.

Angelopoulos’s slow, subtle style has been contrasted with the extraversion of his countryman Costa-Gavras. Costa-Gavras is best-known for this darkly comic 1969 film in which The Deputy is assassinated via clubbing.
Angelopoulos is often compared to a director from this country known for films like Red Psalm. A man from this country directed the seven-plus-hour film Sátántangó.

bonuses.leadin: These phenomena result in sharp discontinuities in the opto·electronic properties of materials and are sometimes known as the critical points of the Brillouin zone. For 10 points each:
answers: linear [accept directly proportional or first power] <Science - Chemistry>
parts: Identify these points that often arise in one-dimensional systems like single-walled carbon nanotubes. They are commonly detected as resonant spikes in Raman spectroscopy.

Van Hove singularities are places in the energy surface where the gradient of this quantity is zero. This quantity is the number of configurations allowed within a given energy interval, and is a continuous generalization of degeneracy.

Graphene’s properties result from the Dirac point, a van Hove singularity that coincides exactly with the chemical potential, with the consequence that the dispersion relation has this dependence on momentum. For a photon, energy has this relationship to momentum and thus frequency.

bonuses.leadin: Prior to his 2019 murder, Gambino crime boss Frank Cali was facing charges for extorting Joseph Vollaro over the construction of a facility for this organization. For 10 points each:
answers: NASCAR [or National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing]
Bill de Blasio [or Warren Wilhelm, Jr.] <Modern World>
parts: Name this organization, whose recent efforts at promoting diversity have been helped by the rise of Daniel Saurez but hindered by the Trump-supporting France family.

Cali’s murder by Anthony Comello turned out not to be a mob hit, but rather due to Comello’s adherence to this movement. Liz Crokin, a leader in this movement, originated its belief that John F. Kennedy, Jr. faked his death and is preparing to emerge on behalf of this group.
Prior to murdering the head of the Gambino crime family on behalf of QAnon, Comello attempted to make a “citizen’s arrest” of this Democratic presidential candidate and current mayor of New York.

bonuses.leadin: The “flagstaffs” of these symbols are crossed by “S”-shaped lines called zülfe. For 10 points each:
answers: Hans Holbein the Younger [accept Holbein rugs] <Arts - Visual>
parts: Name these insignias, which contain two loops on the left, three vertical lines in the middle, and a calligraphic mess of words on the bottom.
Tughras hang above the gates of this palace in Istanbul. Its museum houses Gentile Bellini’s portrait of Mehmed the Conqueror.

The Topkapı Palace museum also houses many of this artist’s namesake style of Anatolian rug. This man painted the most famous portrait of Erasmus, and one of his earliest paintings depicts “Jakob Meyer.”

bonuses.leadin: The debate over the precise value of this quantity prompted a broadside from Thomas Huxley directed at Lord Kelvin, who, according to Huxley, had calculated a value many orders of magnitude too small. For 10 points each:
answers: age of the earth [accept reasonable descriptions]
parts: Identify this disputed quantity, which Kelvin had calculated by assuming a uniformly cooling sphere.

A more-or-less definitive figure of 4.55 billion years was obtained by Clair Patterson using lead-lead dating of these meteorites, fragments of an asteroid that formed the Barringer Crater in Arizona.
Barringer Crater was formed in this geologic epoch, during which the last Yellowstone eruption occurred. The Bonneville and Missoula floods occurred in this geologic epoch.

bonuses.leadin: Over 400 members of this group died at the Battle of Adégon, where they managed to kill only six french soldiers. For 10 points each:
parts: Give the common nickname applied by Westerners to a group of warriors who were known as Mino in their kingdom’s native Fon language. Zora Neale Hurston’s book Barracoon describes the experiences of Cudjo Lewis, who was transported on the Clotilda after his capture by this group during one of their many slave raids.

The Fon people of Dahomey were the first to practice this religion, whose ceremonies constituted the Annual Customs began by King Agaja. Slaves from the region surrounding Dahomey brought this religion to Haiti.

This king of Dahomey overthrew his brother Adandozan with the help of Portugese slaver Francisco Felix de Sousa. This man long resisted British attempts to force an end to the Dahomey slave trade, and his many personal slaves included Sara Forbes Bonetta, who later became a goddaughter of Queen Victoria.

bonuses.leadin: A psychologist of this last name synthesized her work on spatial cognition in her 2019 book Mind in Motion: How Action Shapes Thought. For 10 points each:
answers: Tversky [accept Barbara Tversky or Amos Tversky]
anchoring [or focalism; accept anchoring and adjustment] <Social Science>
parts: Give this last name also shared by a psychologist who ran a series of experiments with Eric Johnson in which subjects read a newspaper account of a tragic death and then estimated the societal frequency of undesirable events.
Both Barbara Tversky and her husband Amos were longtime professors at this university, where Walter Mischel carried out his marshmallow experiment.

Amos Tversky wrote a paper with Daniel Kahneman detailing the representativeness bias, availability bias, and this bias, in which people do not change their views heavily from when they were given initial information.

bonuses.leadin: This group’s transatlantic touring is compared at length to Jimi Hendrix’s in Paul Gilroy’s The Black Atlantic. For 10 points each:
answers: The Souls of Black Folk (by W. E. B. du Bois)
parts: Name this a cappella group, whose extensive touring and recording since 1871 helped popularize traditional black music, as well as being a major funding source for its university.
The Jubilee Singers’ “pilgrimage” was recounted in the final chapter of this book, which includes the text and sheet music of a spiritual as the epigraph for each chapter.

In 1909, the Jubilee Singers made an especially acclaimed recording of this spiritual that possibly inspired a theme in the New World Symphony. The title vehicle of this spiritual is “Coming for to take me home.”

bonuses.leadin: The notorious court case State v. Mann inspired this novel’s character Judge Clayton, who rules that Mr. Baker should not be punished for drunkenly assaulting and then shooting Milly. For 10 points each:
answers: Dred: A Tale of the Great Dismal Swamp
Cora [or Cora Munro (from The Last of the Mohicans)] <Literature - American>
parts: Name this novel in which Harry Gordon is torn over whether or not to join the title character, who lives as a fugitive while prophesying impending doom.
Harriet Beecher Stowe partially based Dred on this slave. His “confessions” to the attorney Thomas Gray inspired a novel by William Styron.

In Dred, the evil lawyer Mr. Jekyl ensures that Harry Gordon’s sister, who has this first name, is sold back into slavery. In an earlier novel, a woman with this first name pleads with Tamenund to free her younger sister after they are kidnapped by Magua.

bonuses.leadin: The first of this book’s three volumes ends with a chapter titled for “What is Possible.” For 10 points each:
answers: Critique of Everyday Life [or Critique de la vie quotidienne]
Karl Marx [accept word forms like Marxist]
right to the city [or droit à la ville] <Philosophy>
parts: Identify this book that focuses on the connection between alienation and the trivialities associated with the title concept. It was a major influence on the 1968 student protests in Frrance.

Critique of Everyday Life is the best-known work of Henri Lefebvre, a sociologist who drew many of his ideas from this Gerrman theorist, whose many catchy concepts include the economic “base” and the political “superstructure.”

In a 1968 work, Lefebfre introduced this concept, which consists in participation and appropriation. According to this idea, its namesake environments are to be structured according to the desires of those who lived within them.

bonuses.leadin: In MD simulations, rigid water molecules are usually modeled by solving the constraint equations analytically after calculating Lagrange multipliers, rather than by this algorithm. For 10 points each:
answers: force fields [or energy functions; prompt on force or energy or potential energy] <Science - Physics>
parts: Name this algorithm in molecular dynamics. The linearized constraint equations are iteratively solved via the Gauss–Seidel method in this algorithm.
Values for this quantity are usually fixed when using the SHAKE algorithm. The fact that X-ray diffraction analysis of benzene reports only a single value for this quantity is evidence of resonance.

CHARMM is a heuristic example of one of these entities in molecular dynamics simulations, which refer to the functional form and parameter sets used in MD interatomic potentials. Rosetta’s 2015 version of them has 19 total parameters.

bonuses.leadin: Many of these events were held at the Hôtel Thellusson. Or possibly they didn’t, because they weren’t real. For 10 points each:
answers: guillotine [prompt on decapitation and similar descriptive answers]
parts: Give the common name for these supposed parties attended by relatives of people executed during the Reign of Terror, which grew in popularity after the death of Maximilien Robespierre. David Bell is pretty convinced that these events are among the most notable fabrications of European history.
Supposedly, dancers at victims’ balls would at times abruptly jerk their heads forward, in imitation of this common method of execution during the Reign of Terror.

During the Reign of Terror, Jean-Baptiste Carrier executed priests and nuns in this city en masse by drowning them in the Loire River, which Carrier nicknamed the “national bathtub.” The so-called “Saint of Anjou,” Jacques Cathelineau, died while leading a mob into this city during the War in the Vendée.

bonuses.leadin: In 1893, this previously-unknown actress became a star by performing the title role of Arthur Wing Pinero’s play The Second Mrs. Tanqueray. For 10 points each:
answers: Mrs. Patrick Campbell [or Stella Patrick Campbell; or Mrs. Pat; or Beatrice Stella Tanner]
parts: Name this British actress. She controversially said “not bloody likely” at the premiere of Pygmalion, where she played Eliza Doolittle, a role George Bernard Shaw wrote for her.

Shaw, who adored Mrs. Patrick Campbell, used her as a model for this play’s character Hesione Hushabye. In this play, Hesione invites Ellie Dunn to the title location to persuade Ellie not to marry Boss Mangan.

For the 100th anniversary of Ibsen’s birth, Mrs. Patrick Campbell played Mrs. Alving in this tragedy, which had been banned in Britain for years. That performance also starred a young John Gielgud as the syphilitic Oswald.

bonuses.leadin: A fatwa from Omar Abdel-Rahman, a 1993 World Trade Center bombing co-conspirator, authorized this event. For 10 points each:
answers: Muslim Brotherhood [or Society of the Muslim Brothers or Jamā’at al-Ikhwān al-Muslimīn] <History - Mediterranean+>
parts: Identify this event that took place during a celebration for the eighth anniversary of Operation Badr. It was carried out by a group under Khalid Islambouli, who approached the target with three hand grenades concealed in his helmet.

Islamic fundamentalists in Egypt also carried out the 1992 killing of this journalist and secularist, who was condemned by religious scholars at al-Azhar. This man’s theorized “Iranian model” and “Lebanese model” ended up mapping strikingly well to the next three decades of Middle Eastern history.
Fundamentalist views in Egypt are often traced to the 1920s formation of this transnational Islamist political party, which got Mohamed Morsi elected in Egypt in 2012. It didn’t go well.

bonuses.leadin: This book describes many experiments with Drosophila pseudo·obscura in Thomas Hunt Morgan’s lab. For 10 points each:
answers: Genetics and the Origin of Species (by Theodosius Dobzhansky)
modern synthesis [prompt on partial answer; accept synthetic theory]
parts: Name this book that coined the term reproductive isolation and promoted its author’s idea of hybrid sterility. It fleshes out the first version of the biological species concept in the chapter “Species as Natural Units.”
Genetics and the Origin of Species is a foundational text for this approach to evolutionary biology. This two-word term denotes the fusion of Darwinian natural selection and Mendelian genetics.

One of the many theories claiming to be the “new synthesis” is this man’s version of sociobiology, which has been accused of biological determinism. This Harvard professor and ant expert devised the theory of island biogeography with Robert MacArthur.

bonuses.leadin: The National Cartoonist Society gives out an annual award named for this man. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this artist whose strip The Inventions of Professor Lucifer Gorgonzola Butts showcased the complicated, impractical machines for performing mundane tasks that became known by his name.
This illustrator of the collection Absurdities was the British counterpart of Rube Goldberg. A mechanical computer replaced by the Colossus at Bletchley Park was named for him.

This Swiss-born artist was inspired by Rube Goldberg machines to create some of his more complicated, longer-lasting sculptures, which unlike his Study for an End of the World No. 2 and Homage to New York, were not intended to self-destruct during viewing. He and Niki de Saint Phalle designed the Stravinsky Founntain.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each—answer the following about the craze for sonnet sequences in Elizabethan England:
answers: Lady Mary Wroth (The sonnet sequence is Pamphilia to Amphilanthus.)
parts: A sonnet sequence by this author includes a crown of 14 sonnets that opens and closes with the line “In this strange labyrinth how shall I turn?” That sonnet sequence depicts the relationship between characters with names meaning “all-loving” and “lover of two.”
Mary Wroth was the niece of this author. He touched off the sonnet sequence craze by writing Astrophil and Stella.

This author’s sonnet “Since there’s no help, come let us kiss and part,” which is sometimes called “Love’s Farewell,” is part of his sonnet sequence Idea. Before his death, he wrote the historic poem The Battle of Agincourt and the mock-epic fairy poem Nymphidia.
